content.description: The crux is commiting to the moves off the ground...there is hardly any gear and it's fiddly fooey for the first 25 feet. It has jugs without the security of much gear.
content.protection: All gear, no bolts, natural crack, and no anchors.
content.location: Seek and you shall find. This starts 10 feet left of the Crow's Corner.  Walk off.

content.description:
Start in the same corner as

Parting of the Red Sea

, but go straight up instead of left. Bear right at the steep but swell crack going right at the end.
content.protection: 100% natural gear including a bomber gear anchor at the top, walk off.
content.location:
This is just left of

David and Goliath

.

content.description: The crux is off the 2nd pitch. It's a slabby but fun, relaxing, and enjoyable 4 pitches. The gear is a little spread but good.
content.protection: All gear, no bolts, no anchors.
content.location: This is the leftmost slabby jaunt. Start at an overgrown base with giant timbers abound. Walk off.

content.description: Several sections are challenging. It is very gunky. There has a good variety on shady rock. Start in short corner to gain a slab with some horizontology. Go up more corners to a short, angling handcrack.
content.protection: All gear, no bolts, and no anchors.
content.location: This route is up the gully just above western-most corner of the lower formation. Walk off.

content.description: The crux is near the top. This is short, steep, shady, and fun.
content.protection: All gear, no bolts, and a good gear anchor.
content.location: Go up a hidden gully on north-facing wall. This is eastmost. It is a steep, semi-splitter corner. Walk off.

content.description: The crux is the awkward, angling, transitional crack down low.
content.protection: All gear, no bolts, and no anchors.
content.location:
The route is up the gully 20-30 feet right of

Isiah 40

. Walk off.

content.description: The crux is getting in bomber gear...it's easy but a little committing for a 7.
content.location:
It's the easy way to the

Amazing Grace

anchor, from the right...start in a corner and head up and left to gain a flaky crack. Fun.

content.description: Climb up a short, rampy corner, then bust left to a short, rattly, but sharp fingers to hands crack. There is lots of cool lichen....then gain some nice feet to bust back right to a tight hands corner. Continue up and left slightly to a nice tree.
content.location:
This is located just right of

Noah And The Ark

. Walk off to the east.

content.description: The crux is about 40' off the deck at the nice, angled finger crack with small feet.
content.protection: Standard rack. There are no bolts!
content.location:
This is to the right of

Johnna And The Whale

. Start in a small recess. Walk off.

content.description:
This route sort of follows the ridge line from right to left on the lowest West-facing rock formation. Start far right on the southernmost rock formation heading up a slab with some cracks, possibly the furthest rightmost route on the wall before turning into broken blocks facing south.

P1. Head up and slightly trending left to a series of cracks and slabs, and aim to go in the middle of two trees above. It’s almost a full 70m pitch. Build an anchor before a steep headwall, 220’, 5.6.

P2. There are multiple options to go up the headwall. We went to the left and then up a right-angling crack which plopped us on the ridge line. Head right towards the trees and sling and anchor, 115’, 5.8-.

P3. We untied and moved the rope climber's right 30’ past the big tree (you should be standing on a big ledge before the final headwall) to the base of the twin cracks leading up to the actual summit. Head up the twin cracks, and follow the crack up. After pulling the bulge, jog up the ridge, and build an anchor among the blocks at the top, 115’,  5.9.
content.protection: A standard double rack with a #4 is what we used. We had some gear to spare.
content.location: Follow the West-facing wall downwards until the lower wall starts curving to the south. The base of the climb is covered in pine needles with no loose rocks. Refer to the pictures for where the start is.

content.description: The mental crux is low and involves commiting gear. The gear gets much better. The technical crux at mid height is reachy. This has amazing climbing all the way.
content.protection: All gear, small wires off the deck, no bolts, and no anchor. There is good gear at the top.
content.location: This route is on the low northwest corner of the lower formation. Walk off. It just right of a significant guano heap.

content.description: The crux is a toss up between pitches 2 and 3. It has a fun crux. Head up and a little right through a steep crack. Belay on a ledge. Traverse right through a rattly overhang that pulls right once again. Walk off.
content.protection: There is one bolted belay at the end of the 1st pitch.
content.location: The route starts just below a right-angling, downward pointing flake.
